awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Geometrically Optimal Gait Optimization
awd_abstract_narration:
Animal locomotion is difficult to model accurately from first principles, and idealized mathematical approximations often neglect potentially significant physical effects. Yet these mathematical descriptions are the most powerful tools available to understand natural movement, and to replicate its effectiveness in engineered robotic systems. This project combines a powerful mathematical analysis and design framework with a data-driven method for developing predictive relations that reflect observed behavior. The geometric control approach allows the construction of motions that optimize certain beneficial attributes, such as the efficiency of travel, but requires comprehensive mathematical models of the dynamics. On the other hand, Data-Driven Floquet Analysis (DDFA) allows modeling of the dynamics of repetitive motions based on observations, but provides only a narrow portrait of the system behavior. This project will apply DDFA to construct geometric models, which will then enable use of the methods of geometric control to find desirable gaits. By building locomotion models from the observed outputs of the system's physical processes, this project will allow the complexities of real motions to be accommodated into powerful geometric design frameworks, with an efficient use of measurements. The results will advance the nation's prosperity and welfare by enabling robots that walk, swim, or crawl robustly and efficiently, for missions such as search-and-rescue or environmental monitoring. The project will also give insight on the locomotion strategy of animals. The project includes a student outreach component, with modules that provide hands-on learning about gaits.
 
This project combines two paradigms which consider whole-body interaction between a system and its environment from a rigorous mathematical perspective. One approach, based on gauge theory and geometric mechanics, looks at how the system dynamics vary across the configuration space. This global perspective allows for optimal gaits to be defined and their characteristics studied, but relies on detailed system models. The second approach, rooted in Floquet theory, views the gait cycle as fixed and analyzes perturbations away from its cyclic motions. In this perspective, a gait is a set of coupled oscillations in body shape and velocity. This body of work seeks to understand the nature of the coupling through empirical observation, but provides only local views of the system dynamics near fixed gaits, and does not provide clear vectors along which to optimize those gaits. This project unifies the geometric and data-driven Floquet paradigms in a way that combines their strengths while mitigating their weaknesses. It brings geometric notions of optimality into Floquet analysis and data-driven modeling techniques from the Floquet paradigm into the geometric modeling approach. Experiments on a range of systems with different body topologies and environmental interactions will play a key role in both the development and evaluation of this new framework.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
From a robot's perspective, animal locomotion is extremely impressive. Animals efficiently move over unpredictable terrain while drawing in few processing resources. They recover their gait with remarkable agility, in many cases (such as with ants and cockroaches), doing so even after substantial structural damage. By contrast, most robots rely on an extremely limited set of wheel-based strategies that cope very poorly with most of the earth's terrain.

Robot designers who better understand how animal locomotion arises from whole-body interactions with the environment can create better field robots, capable of moving over sand, broken terrain, or rubble. That is especially important in some applications, like rescue robots or the scouting and exploration of inhospitable or extremely dangerous environments. But it also has broader, more mundane applications, improving commercial robots used in delivery, security monitoring, or logistics. Understanding gait optimality also provides testable biological hypotheses of motion, with potential applications in prosthesis and orthosis design, and contributions to the basic science of biology.

All of this requires a rigorous mathematical approach to understanding the links between shape and body motions. As it stands, two dominant approaches to this problem exist. One is based on geometric mechanics. This approach allows for optimal gaits, but demands extremely detailed modeling (which is resource intensive). The other approach (rooted in Floquet theory) sees gaits as sets of coupled oscillations in body shape and velocity. This empirical approach is good for describing observed gaits, but does poorly at predicting the influence of changes to the gait.

The work funded under this grant aimed to unify these two approaches. Combining these two views with a rigorous means of empirically building system models from experimental results promised to make it possible to control the motions of systems which cannot be feasibly modeled through analytical or numerical approaches, while achieving locomotion through a more "natural" strategy based on whole-body motions that exploit shape-dependent changes in body dynamics.

From the beginning, a key feature of this project was tight integration of theory and experiment to iteratively build a model (as opposed to using a more typical "first principles" model-prediction-test framework). To this end we developed several new robot platforms, including "Multipod" robots with up to 12 legs (used to study gaits at various levels of morphological complexity), "Spyderbot" (a six-legged insect-like robot with 3 degrees of freedom per leg, created specifically for its large state space and highly nonlinear dynamics, characteristics that make control via existing methods quite difficult), "BigAnt" (a six-legged robot with one motor per leg, used to explore simple locomotion strategies that require slipping) and "MediumAnt" (a sub-$200 version of "BigAnt", designed to be more accessible to a broader range of individuals and institutions interested in exploring locomotion).

We published our key results in the Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences [Zhao et al., 2022]. This publication demonstrated that models unifying slipping and non-slipping motion can describe multi-legged animals and robots with the formalism that is known to describe swimming and slithering. This provides both a substantial simplification of the models of these systems--one with practical applications in robot design--as well as offering a potential insight into the evolution of motor control in animals.  Additional, more technical results were published in multiple scientific journals and presented in conferences.

From a practical standpoint, this allows for gait optimization and recovery on a family of hard-to-model robots. We demonstrated that the resulting hardware in the loop/Geometrically Optimal Gait Optimization (GOGO) approach not only works well with "conventional" legged robots (like those described above), but also on "unconventional" robots such as, a robot constructed from tree branches. Our results suggest that a roboticist can put together a robot with poorly undertstood structural and material properties, plug it into a smart system identifier, and let simple optimizations (such as GOGO) guide the robot into being a useful navigator, manipulator, and so on.

This grant also supported the creation of materials and guides to make elements of this work accessible to a broader audience, and provide students with a hands-on experience in scientific robotics, engineering, the scientific method, and some of the surprising biomechanics of animal locomotion. These materials included an outreach website, MI Legged Robots
(https://mileggedrobots.eecs.umich.edu/), which facilitates teachers and student building affordable legged robots. We also developed several low-cost laboratory robot platforms (i.e., MediumANT and NSF Project Inchworm) that allow high schoolers to explore rapid robot prototyping and implementation of simplified forms of GOGO.
